Title: Defense Mutualisms Enhance Plant Diversification
Keywords:
Mutualism, extrafloral nectaries, key innovation, lineage
diversification rates, plant defense, macroevolution, phylogenetics,
plant-insect interactions
Abstract:
The ability of plants to form mutualistic relationships
with animal-defenders has long been suspected to influence their
evolutionary success, both by decreasing extinction risk and by
increasing opportunity for speciation through an expanded realized
niche. However, the hypothesis that defense mutualism consistently
enhance plant diversification across lineages has not been well-tested
due to a lack of phenotypic and phylogenetic information. Using a global
analysis, we show that among the >100 vascular plant families that
have evolved plant organs that recruit arthropod mutualists, extrafloral
nectaries, have two-fold higher diversification rates than families that
lack extrafloral nectaries. In fine-scale examinations of six distantly
related plant groups trait-dependent diversification models confirmed
the tendency for lineages with extrafloral nectaries to display
increased rates of diversification. In sister clade comparisons, we
found greater number of rate shifts in EFN lineages than non-EFN sister
lineages. This replicated analysis indicates that defense mutualisms put
lineages on a path towards increased diversification rates within and
between clades, and is concordant with the hypothesis that deep
macroevolutionary patterns of plant diversity are impacted by local
mutualistic interactions with animals.
